Home  >  GM studies at Broom's Barn
Economic consequences for UK farmers of growing GM herbicide tolerant sugar beet

The first analysis of the potential economic benefit of commercial production of a GM herbcide tolerant (GMHT) crop in the UK has been published by Broom's Barn Research Station (the national centre for sugar beet research) in Suffolk. The study specifically concerns sugar beet and the key finding is that overall savings
column2: net of technology fee included in the seed price
column4: or £23m per year if GMHT crops were grown exclusively. A major part of this saving is the 80% reduction in expenditure on herbicides. The paper has been published in the peer reviewed scientific journal

column3: Senior Liaison Officer at Broom's Barn said: "Research results reported earlier this year showed that management of GMHT sugar beet had the potential to provide environmental benefit. This economic analysis now quantifies the potential financial benefits of growing GMHT beet and thus the positive impact on industry competitiveness and affordability of agri-environment measures. Broadly similar cost savings could also be realised in much of Europe. The potential saving that GM herbicide tolerant (GMHT) sugar beet provides could be critical to the future competitiveness of the UK sugar beet industry.

column1: The current EU regime ends in 2006 and it is expected that the price for sugar beet will reduce. Sugar beet is a major spring sown break crop and if production declines as a consequence of reduced profitability
column2: this could intensify winter cropping in the UK with possible environmental consequences and less scope for integrated crop management practices.

column1: The reduced cost of beet production if GMHT were adopted could be critical to the establishment and economic viability of an ethanol based biofuel induestry in the UK
column2: boosting the rural economy and helping the UK to meet its EU and Kyoto Protocol greenhouse gas emission commitments."

column1: Genetically modified crops offer hope for endangered wildlife
In the first piece of research into how genetically modified (GM) herbicide tolerant crops could be used to benefit the environment
column2: scientists* from Broom's Barn Research Station in Suffolk show that creative use of GM crops could bring back increasing numbers of endangered wildlife and birds such as skylarks and finches.  This new research
column3: to be published in Philosophical Transactions B
column4: a learned journal produced by the Royal Society
column5: suggests that GM herbicide tolerant crops could be a powerful tool in developing sustainable farming systems in the future.

column1: The research is based on a new weed-management system for GM sugar beet
column2: demonstrating that weeds can be retained for longer without affecting the crop yield.  The weeds and associated insects provide vital food and habitats for the farmland birds and other wildlife
column3: which have dramatically declined as a result of intensive farming systems.
says:  "Frequent spraying destroys the weeds on which the insects and birds feed
column4: but our system means we can reduce the amount of spraying and allow weeds between the rows to flourish in summer without affecting yield. Our method could easily be applied to other row crops.

column1: "We are excited about our results because this is the first time research has shown that GM herbicide tolerant crops can be managed for environmental benefit. This marks a vital contribution to the GM debate
column3: has been largely focused on fears of possible negative impact.  The environmental benefits are particularly important for the UK and the rest of Europe
column4: where around 80 per cent of the land is farmed
column5:
he says.

* A novel approach to the use of genetically modified herbicide tolerant crops for environmental benefit, by: Alan M Dewar; Mike J May; Ian P Woiwood; Lisa A Haylock; Gillian T Champion; Beulah H Garner; Richard J Sands; Aiming Qi and John D Pidgeon.

PLEASE ACKNOWLEDGE THE ROYAL SOCIETY PROCEEDINGS B AS THE SOURCE FOR ANY INFORMATION USED

The Royal Society is an independent academy promoting the natural and applied sciences. Founded in 1660, the Society has three roles, as the UK academy of science, as a learned Society and as a funding agency. It responds to individual demand with selection by merit not by field. The Society's objectives are:

  • Recognise excellence in science
  • Support leading-edge scientific research and its applications
  • Stimulate international interaction
  • Further the role of science, engineering and technology in society
  • Promote education and public understanding of science
  • Provide independent authoritative advice on matters relating to science, engineering and technology
  • Encourage research into the history of science

Contact details for Royal Society Press and Public Relations Office: Tim Watson, tel: +44 (0) 20 7451 2508

For further information about the activities of Broom's Barn, or the GM studies in particular, please contact Mike May mike.may@bbsrc.ac.uk
